Operations on Octet Sequences

In TJS2, octet sequences are pseudo-treated as objects of the Octet class, but the Octet class does not actually exist, nor are they truly objects of an Octet class (however, using the typeof operator on an octet sequence will return "Octet").
Nevertheless, by treating octet sequences as objects, several methods and properties become available.

The implementation regarding octet sequences is incomplete.

length

The length property returns the length of the octet sequence. Please note that it is a property, not a method. However, you cannot assign a value to this property.


Example:
    var oct = <% 11 22 33 %>;
    var n = oct.length;  // 3 is assigned to n
    var n = <% 11 22 33 %>.length; // Similarly, 3 is assigned to this as well

'Numeric' Property

By specifying a number indirectly as a property, you can access the octet at that position.
The result is represented as the numeric value of the octet.
For example, if oct is an expression representing an octet sequence, oct[0] will be the numeric value representing the first octet.
An exception will occur if the number points to a position beyond the length of the octet sequence or if it is negative.

Assignment expressions cannot be generated.

Example:
    var oct = <% 11 22 33 44 55 %>;
    var c = oct[0];  // 0x11 is assigned to c
    var c = oct[2];  // 0x33 is assigned to c
    oct[3] = 'A'; // Error because assignment expressions cannot be generated
    var c = oct[100]; // Error because the value is out of range

unpack

The unpack method converts binary (Octet) data into an array (Array) and returns it according to the string specified in the argument.
The specified string is called a template.
A template consists of format characters and their lengths. When * is specified as the length, it represents all remaining length. If the length is omitted, it is treated as 1.

Syntax : unpack(template_string)
The following characters can be used in the template string:
a : ASCII string (padded with null characters)
A : ASCII string (padded with spaces)
b : Bit string (ascending bit order)
B : Bit string (descending bit order)
c : Signed 1-byte integer (-128 to 127)
C : Unsigned 1-byte integer (0 to 255)
d : Double-precision floating-point value
f : Single-precision floating-point value
h : Hexadecimal string (low nibble first)
H : Hexadecimal string (high nibble first)
i : Signed int (usually 4 bytes)
I : Unsigned int (usually 4 bytes)
l : Signed long (usually 4 bytes)
L : Unsigned long (usually 4 bytes)
n : Unsigned short (network byte order)
N : Unsigned long (network byte order)
s : Signed short (usually 2 bytes)
S : Unsigned short (usually 2 bytes)
v : Unsigned short (little-endian)
V : Unsigned long (little-endian)
x : Skip 1 byte
X : Back up 1 byte
@ : Move to absolute position
m : Base64 decode

Example:
    var array = octet.unpack("a4i2");
In this example, the first 4 bytes of octet are treated as ASCII characters, and a 4-character string is output to the 0th element of the array.
Next, the following 8 bytes are treated as two 32-bit signed integers and output to the 1st and 2nd elements of the array.
That is, a string like "xxxx" is output to array[0], and integers are output to array[1] and array[2].
